batchMetadata.description: Advanced governmental accounting including fund accounting, budgetary accounting, and GASB standards

questions.question: A city has the following fund information: General Fund assets $50 million, Special Revenue Fund A assets $8 million, Special Revenue Fund B assets $3 million, Capital Projects Fund assets $12 million, total governmental fund assets $73 million. Enterprise Fund X assets $25 million, Enterprise Fund Y assets $4 million, total enterprise fund assets $29 million. Which funds are considered major funds under GASB 34?

options.A: General Fund and Enterprise Fund X only
options.B: General Fund, Capital Projects Fund, and Enterprise Fund X
options.C: General Fund, Special Revenue Fund A, Capital Projects Fund, and Enterprise Fund X
options.D: All funds listed are major funds

questions.explanation: A fund is major if: (1) total assets, liabilities, revenues, or expenditures are at least 10% of the corresponding total for all funds of that category (governmental or enterprise), AND (2) at least 5% of the corresponding total for all governmental and enterprise funds combined. General Fund is always major. Capital Projects ($12M) is 16.4% of governmental ($73M) and 11.8% of combined ($102M) - major. Special Revenue A ($8M) is 11% of governmental but only 7.8% of combined - needs both tests. Enterprise X ($25M) is 86% of enterprise and 24.5% of combined - major.
questions.tip: Major fund tests: 10% of category AND 5% of combined total. General Fund is always major regardless of size.

questions.question: At year-end, a city's General Fund has outstanding encumbrances of $150,000 for supplies on order. The city does not have a legal requirement to honor these commitments. How should this be reported in the government-wide financial statements?

options.A: As a liability of $150,000
options.B: As restricted fund balance of $150,000
options.C: As committed fund balance of $150,000
options.D: Not reported; encumbrances are eliminated in conversion

questions.explanation: Encumbrances are budgetary accounts used in governmental fund accounting to record commitments for future expenditures. They are part of the modified accrual basis and are not recognized in government-wide statements, which use accrual accounting. In fund financial statements, outstanding encumbrances are typically reported as committed or assigned fund balance, but they are eliminated when converting to government-wide statements.
questions.tip: Government-wide statements use full accrual basis - budgetary accounts like encumbrances are eliminated in conversion.

questions.question: A state government uses the modified approach for its highway system infrastructure. During the current year, the state spent $5 million on resurfacing roads to maintain them at condition level 7 (the established target). How should this be reported?

options.A: Capitalized as infrastructure additions
options.B: Expensed as maintenance in the government-wide statements
options.C: Capitalized and depreciated over the useful life
options.D: Reported as a reduction of accumulated depreciation

questions.explanation: Under the modified approach (GASB 34), eligible infrastructure assets are not depreciated if the government: (1) manages the assets using an asset management system, (2) documents the condition level, and (3) estimates annual costs to maintain/preserve at the established condition level. Instead of depreciation, preservation and maintenance costs are expensed as incurred. The $5 million resurfacing cost is expensed, not capitalized.
questions.tip: Modified approach: No depreciation on infrastructure; maintenance/preservation costs are expensed. Must meet three requirements and document condition assessments.

questions.question: A county administers a defined benefit pension plan for its employees. In the pension trust fund, how should the net pension liability be reported?

options.A: As a liability in the pension trust fund
options.B: As a liability in the government-wide statement of net position
options.C: Both in the pension trust fund and government-wide statements
options.D: Only disclosed in the notes to financial statements

questions.explanation: The net pension liability (total pension liability minus plan fiduciary net position) is not reported in the pension trust fund. Pension trust funds report assets held in trust and do not record the liability. The net pension liability is reported by the employer government in its government-wide statement of net position. The pension trust fund reports the plan fiduciary net position (plan assets minus plan liabilities for benefits currently due).
questions.tip: Net pension liability belongs on employer's government-wide statements, not in the pension trust fund. Trust fund shows plan net position only.

questions.question: A city's General Fund loans $500,000 to its Water Enterprise Fund with a requirement to repay within 18 months. How should this transaction be reported in the fund financial statements?

options.A: Transfer out in General Fund, Transfer in in Enterprise Fund
options.B: Due from Enterprise Fund in General Fund, Due to General Fund in Enterprise Fund
options.C: Expenditure in General Fund, Revenue in Enterprise Fund
options.D: Interfund advance to Enterprise Fund in General Fund, Interfund advance from General Fund in Enterprise Fund

questions.explanation: Interfund loans expected to be repaid are classified as either 'due to/from' if repayable within one year, or 'advances to/from' if not expected to be repaid within one year. Since this loan is repayable in 18 months (more than one year), it should be reported as an interfund advance. Advances are distinguished from transfers, which represent permanent reallocations between funds with no expectation of repayment.
questions.tip: Due to/from = current (within 1 year). Advances = noncurrent. Transfers = no repayment expected.

questions.question: On November 1, Year 1, a city levied property taxes of $10,000,000 for Year 2 operations. The taxes are legally due on January 1, Year 2, and the city estimates 2% will be uncollectible. The city collected $4,000,000 by December 31, Year 1, and expects to collect $5,500,000 in January-February Year 2. What amount should the city recognize as property tax revenue in Year 1?
questions.explanation: Under modified accrual accounting, property tax revenue is recognized when it becomes measurable and available. 'Available' typically means collectible within the current period or soon enough thereafter to pay current liabilities (usually 60 days). Although $4 million was collected in Year 1, these taxes were levied for Year 2 operations. The taxes are not revenue until the fiscal period for which they were levied (Year 2). Revenue recognition follows the 'for which levied' concept.
questions.tip: Property taxes: Revenue in the period 'for which levied,' not when collected. The levy date determines the year of revenue recognition.

questions.question: A city issues $5,000,000 of general obligation bonds at 103 to finance construction of a new fire station. The premium must be used for debt service per the bond covenant. How much should be recorded in the Capital Projects Fund?

options.D: $5,000,000 plus a transfer to Debt Service Fund

questions.explanation: The face value of bonds ($5,000,000) is recorded in the Capital Projects Fund as an other financing source. The premium of $150,000 ($5,000,000 × 3%) must be transferred to the Debt Service Fund per the covenant. This is typically recorded as: Capital Projects Fund receives $5,000,000 (other financing source - bond proceeds), then transfers $150,000 to Debt Service Fund (other financing use - transfer out). The net in Capital Projects is $5,000,000 face amount.
questions.tip: Bond premiums restricted for debt service go to Debt Service Fund. Capital Projects Fund typically receives face value only.

questions.question: A city's General Fund reports the following: Expenditures for equipment $300,000 (useful life 10 years), Principal payment on bonds $200,000, Interest paid on bonds $50,000 (includes $10,000 accrued from prior year). What is the total adjustment to convert expenditures to expenses for government-wide reporting?

options.A: Decrease expenses by $260,000
options.B: Decrease expenses by $280,000
options.C: Decrease expenses by $470,000
options.D: Decrease expenses by $480,000

questions.explanation: Conversion adjustments: (1) Equipment expenditure $300,000 replaced with depreciation $30,000 ($300,000/10), net decrease $270,000. (2) Principal payment $200,000 removed (debt repayment is not an expense under accrual). (3) Interest: $50,000 paid but only $40,000 is current year expense (prior year accrual $10,000 already expensed), decrease $10,000. Total decrease: $270,000 + $200,000 + $10,000 = $480,000.
questions.tip: Government-wide conversion: Replace capital outlay with depreciation, remove debt principal, adjust interest for accruals.

questions.question: A city's General Fund has the following constraints on resources: State law requires 5% of revenues be reserved for emergencies. City council has adopted a policy to maintain a 10% stabilization amount. The council has indicated intent to use $500,000 for next year's capital purchases. How should these be classified in fund balance?

options.A: All three are restricted fund balance
options.B: State requirement is restricted; council policy and intent are committed
options.C: State requirement is restricted; council policy is committed; intent is assigned
options.D: All three are committed fund balance

questions.explanation: Fund balance classifications under GASB 54: (1) State law creating a constraint is restricted fund balance - imposed by external parties. (2) Council-adopted stabilization policy is committed fund balance - formal council action that requires similar action to remove. (3) Intent for capital purchases is assigned fund balance - intended use set by management but not formally committed by highest decision-making authority. Committed requires formal action; assigned requires only intent.
questions.tip: Restricted = external constraints. Committed = formal government action. Assigned = intended purpose without formal commitment.

questions.question: Which of the following would NOT qualify for reporting as a special revenue fund under GASB standards?

options.A: A fund accounting for a state gasoline tax legally restricted for road maintenance
options.B: A fund accounting for federal grants restricted for food services
options.C: A fund accounting for general government operations funded by unrestricted property taxes
options.D: A fund accounting for hotel taxes committed by the city council for tourism promotion

questions.explanation: Special revenue funds are used to account for and report the proceeds of specific revenue sources that are restricted or committed to expenditure for specified purposes other than debt service or capital projects. Unrestricted property taxes for general operations do not meet the criteria - they should be reported in the General Fund. Options A, B, and D all have specific restrictions or commitments on revenue use.
questions.tip: Special revenue funds require restricted or committed revenues for specific purposes. General purpose revenues belong in the General Fund.

questions.question: A city (lessee) enters into a 5-year lease for office equipment with annual payments of $50,000 due at the end of each year. The city's incremental borrowing rate is 4%. The present value factor for an ordinary annuity at 4% for 5 years is 4.4518. What is the initial lease liability?
questions.explanation: Under GASB 87, lessees recognize a lease liability at the present value of future lease payments. Since payments are made at year-end (ordinary annuity): Lease liability = $50,000 × 4.4518 = $222,590. The city also records an intangible right-to-use lease asset equal to the lease liability plus any prepayments or initial direct costs.
questions.tip: GASB 87: Lessees record lease liability at PV of payments and a corresponding right-to-use asset. Similar to ASC 842 but specific governmental guidance.

questions.question: A government reports: Capital assets $10,000,000, Accumulated depreciation $3,000,000, Capital-related debt $4,500,000, Unspent bond proceeds $800,000, Deferred outflow from debt refunding $200,000. What is net investment in capital assets?
questions.explanation: Net investment in capital assets = Capital assets ($10,000,000) - Accumulated depreciation ($3,000,000) - Capital-related debt ($4,500,000) + Unspent bond proceeds ($800,000) + Deferred outflow from refunding ($200,000) = $3,500,000. Unspent bond proceeds are added back because those funds haven't been used to acquire capital assets yet. Deferred outflows from refunding are added as they represent resources related to debt.
questions.tip: Net investment in capital assets: Net capital assets minus related debt plus unspent proceeds plus related deferred outflows minus related deferred inflows.

questions.question: Under GASB 75, how should a single-employer government report its other postemployment benefits (OPEB) obligation?

options.A: Report total OPEB liability in governmental fund statements only
options.B: Report net OPEB liability in government-wide statements as total liability minus plan fiduciary net position
options.C: Report only the funded portion as a liability
options.D: Disclose the obligation in notes only; no liability recognition required

questions.explanation: Under GASB 75, employers participating in single-employer or agent multiple-employer OPEB plans report a net OPEB liability equal to the total OPEB liability (actuarially determined) minus the OPEB plan's fiduciary net position. This is reported in the government-wide financial statements (or proprietary/fiduciary fund statements). Governmental fund statements do not report long-term liabilities.
questions.tip: GASB 75 mirrors GASB 68 for pensions: Net OPEB liability = Total OPEB liability - Plan net position. Reported on government-wide statements.

questions.question: A city creates a Building Authority that issues debt to construct city facilities. The Authority has a separate governing board, but the city appoints all members, the Authority provides services exclusively to the city, and the city is obligated for the debt. How should the Authority be reported?

options.A: As a discretely presented component unit
options.B: As a blended component unit
options.C: As a joint venture
options.D: Not included in city's financial statements

questions.explanation: A component unit is blended when it meets criteria including: (1) the governing body is substantively the same as the primary government, (2) the component unit provides services entirely or almost entirely to the primary government, or (3) the component unit's debt is expected to be repaid entirely from resources of the primary government. The Building Authority meets multiple blending criteria - it serves only the city and the city is obligated for its debt.
questions.tip: Blending criteria: Same governing body, services almost entirely to primary government, or debt repaid by primary government.

questions.question: A government contributes $1,000,000 to its pension plan after the measurement date but before year-end. How should this be reported?

options.A: Pension expense of $1,000,000
options.B: Reduction of net pension liability of $1,000,000
options.C: Deferred outflow of resources of $1,000,000
options.D: Prepaid pension asset of $1,000,000

questions.explanation: Under GASB 68, contributions made between the measurement date and the employer's year-end are reported as deferred outflows of resources. These contributions will reduce the net pension liability in the subsequent year when the new measurement date net pension liability is calculated. They are not immediately recognized as expense or a reduction of the liability.
questions.tip: Contributions after measurement date = Deferred outflow. They reduce next year's net pension liability when remeasured.

questions.question: Which of the following is required in a governmental entity's budgetary comparison schedule for the General Fund?

options.A: Original budget, final budget, and actual results on the budgetary basis
options.B: Only final budget and actual results on GAAP basis
options.C: Original budget and actual results on GAAP basis only
options.D: Projected budget for next year and actual results

questions.explanation: GASB requires a budgetary comparison schedule (or statement) for the General Fund and each major special revenue fund with a legally adopted budget. The schedule must show: (1) original budget, (2) final amended budget, and (3) actual amounts on the budgetary basis of accounting. A reconciliation to GAAP is required if the budgetary basis differs from GAAP.
questions.tip: Budgetary comparison: Original budget → Final budget → Actual (budgetary basis). Required for General Fund and major special revenue funds with adopted budgets.

questions.question: Which criterion requires mandatory use of an enterprise fund?

options.A: The activity charges fees to external users
options.B: Debt backed solely by fees and charges of the activity is outstanding
options.C: The activity has positive net income
options.D: The governing body elects to use enterprise fund accounting

questions.explanation: Enterprise fund use is required when one of three criteria is met: (1) debt is outstanding backed solely by fees and charges of the activity (including revenue bonds), (2) laws or regulations require cost recovery through fees and charges, or (3) pricing policies are designed to recover costs including capital costs. Outstanding debt backed solely by the activity's revenues (criterion 1) is a mandatory trigger.
questions.tip: Mandatory enterprise fund: Debt backed solely by activity fees, legal cost recovery requirement, or pricing policy for full cost recovery.

questions.question: A city operates a motor pool internal service fund that provides vehicles to other city departments. The fund charges rates that result in a $200,000 profit for the year. How is this profit treated in government-wide statements?

options.A: Reported as revenue in the governmental activities column
options.B: Eliminated because it represents internal profit
options.C: Reported as other financing sources
options.D: Reported in the business-type activities column

questions.explanation: Internal service funds predominantly serve governmental activities and are typically reported with governmental activities in government-wide statements. Since internal service funds charge other departments, any 'profit' represents overcharging - these internal profits must be eliminated in conversion to government-wide statements to avoid overstating expenses. Eliminations are shown in the 'Total' column.
questions.tip: Internal service fund profits/losses are eliminated in government-wide statements. They represent internal transactions, not external profits.

questions.question: A city receives a $2,000,000 state grant for constructing a community center. The grant is expenditure-driven. In Year 1, the city spends $1,500,000 on construction and receives $1,200,000 from the state. What is the Year 1 revenue in the Capital Projects Fund?
questions.explanation: For expenditure-driven (reimbursement) grants under modified accrual, revenue is recognized when expenditures are made (the eligibility requirements are met). The city spent $1,500,000 and therefore can recognize $1,500,000 in grant revenue. The fact that only $1,200,000 was received creates a due from state of $300,000. The remaining $500,000 grant will be recognized when those expenditures are made.
questions.tip: Expenditure-driven grants: Revenue = Qualifying expenditures made, not cash received. Receivable for amounts earned but not received.

questions.question: A citizen donates $500,000 to a city with instructions that the principal be preserved permanently and earnings be used for park maintenance. How should the investment earnings of $30,000 be reported?

options.A: In the General Fund as unrestricted revenue
options.B: In the Permanent Fund as nonspendable fund balance
options.C: In the Permanent Fund as restricted fund balance available for park maintenance
options.D: In a Special Revenue Fund for parks

questions.explanation: Permanent funds account for resources legally restricted so that earnings, not principal, may be used for purposes supporting the government's programs. The $500,000 principal is nonspendable fund balance. The $30,000 earnings are restricted fund balance because they must be used for the specified purpose (park maintenance). The earnings stay in the Permanent Fund until transferred or spent.
questions.tip: Permanent fund: Principal = Nonspendable. Earnings = Restricted (per donor restrictions). Earnings may be transferred to Special Revenue Fund when spent.

questions.question: A state receives $5,000,000 in federal funds that must be passed through to local school districts. The state has administrative involvement and oversight responsibilities. How should the state report this?

options.A: As revenue and expenditure of $5,000,000
options.B: As an agency fund liability only
options.C: As a note disclosure only
options.D: Net, with no revenue or expenditure reported

questions.explanation: When a government has administrative involvement (such as monitoring subrecipients, determining eligibility, or exercising discretion in distribution), pass-through grants are reported as revenue and expenditure in governmental funds. If the government acts merely as a 'cash conduit' with no administrative responsibility, it would use agency fund or net reporting. Administrative oversight makes the state a recipient, not just a pass-through.
questions.tip: Pass-through grants: With administrative involvement = revenue and expenditure. Without involvement (cash conduit) = agency fund or net.

questions.question: A city owes employees $800,000 for accumulated vacation time. The vacation vests and will be paid when employees take time off or terminate. $100,000 is expected to be paid with currently available resources. How is this reported in the General Fund?

options.A: Liability of $800,000
options.B: Liability of $100,000 in fund statements; $800,000 in government-wide statements
options.C: Liability of $700,000 in fund statements; $100,000 in government-wide statements
options.D: No liability; disclosed in notes only

questions.explanation: In governmental fund financial statements, compensated absence liabilities are recognized only to the extent they are 'due and payable' - typically the amount expected to be liquidated with currently available resources (usually what will be paid in the current year). The remaining $700,000 is a long-term liability reported only in government-wide statements. Fund statements: $100,000. Government-wide: $800,000 total.
questions.tip: Governmental funds: Only current portion of compensated absences. Government-wide: Full accrued liability.

questions.question: A city self-insures for workers' compensation claims through an internal service fund. Claims data: Reported claims $1,200,000, IBNR (incurred but not reported) claims estimated at $400,000, Expected recoveries $150,000. What liability should be reported?
questions.explanation: The liability for self-insurance claims includes: reported claims ($1,200,000) plus IBNR claims ($400,000) less expected recoveries ($150,000) = $1,450,000. GASB 10 requires recognition of liabilities for both reported and unreported (IBNR) claims when it is probable a claim has been incurred and the amount can be reasonably estimated.
questions.tip: Self-insurance liability = Reported claims + IBNR claims - Expected recoveries. Include all probable incurred claims.

questions.question: A city operates a landfill with total estimated closure/postclosure costs of $20,000,000. The landfill has a total capacity of 5,000,000 tons and currently contains 3,500,000 tons. What closure liability should be reported in the enterprise fund?
questions.explanation: Under GASB 18, landfill closure and postclosure costs are recognized proportionally as landfill capacity is used. Percentage used = 3,500,000 / 5,000,000 = 70%. Liability = $20,000,000 × 70% = $14,000,000. The liability increases each year as more capacity is consumed.
questions.tip: Landfill closure liability = Total estimated costs × (Capacity used / Total capacity). Proportional recognition based on usage.

questions.question: Which of the following is included in the statistical section of a government's Annual Comprehensive Financial Report (ACFR)?

options.A: Management's Discussion and Analysis
options.B: Ten-year trend data on net position and fund balances
options.C: Notes to the financial statements
options.D: Independent auditor's report

questions.explanation: The statistical section of an ACFR (formerly CAFR) presents trend information, typically for ten years, in five categories: (1) financial trends (net position, fund balance changes), (2) revenue capacity, (3) debt capacity, (4) demographic and economic information, and (5) operating information. MD&A and notes are in basic financial statements; auditor's report is in the introductory or financial section.
questions.tip: Statistical section: 10-year trends in five categories - financial, revenue capacity, debt capacity, demographics, and operating information.

questions.question: A city issues bonds on behalf of a private company to finance construction of a manufacturing facility. The company is obligated for all debt payments, and the city has no legal obligation for repayment. How should the city report this debt?

options.A: As a liability in government-wide statements
options.B: As a liability in an enterprise fund
options.C: As a conduit debt obligation disclosed in notes only
options.D: No reporting required by the city

questions.explanation: Conduit debt obligations are issued by a government on behalf of a third party (typically for economic development) where the third party is responsible for repayment and the government has no obligation beyond the debt proceeds. Under GASB 91, conduit debt is not reported as a liability but requires note disclosure including the aggregate amount outstanding and a general description of the arrangements.
questions.tip: Conduit debt: Government issues but third party repays. Disclosure only, no liability recognized (unless government has commitment).

questions.question: A state government discovers soil contamination on property it owns. Under GASB 49, when should a pollution remediation liability be recognized?

options.A: Only when remediation work begins
options.B: When an obligating event occurs and component costs are reasonably estimable
options.C: Only when legally ordered by environmental agency
options.D: When contamination is discovered regardless of obligating events

questions.explanation: GASB 49 requires recognition of pollution remediation liabilities when: (1) an obligating event occurs (such as permit violation, agency order, government acknowledgment, contamination evidence with legal obligation to act, or property acquisition with contamination) AND (2) the component costs of the remediation are reasonably estimable. Discovery alone does not trigger recognition without an obligating event.
questions.tip: Pollution remediation: Obligating event + Reasonably estimable costs. Use expected cash flows approach weighted by probability.

questions.question: A city levies a 1% sales tax. December Year 1 sales subject to tax totaled $15,000,000. The tax is due from merchants by January 20, Year 2, and the city expects to collect it by February 28, Year 2. The city uses a 60-day availability period. What sales tax revenue should be recognized in Year 1?
questions.explanation: Sales taxes are derived (nonexchange) tax revenues recognized when the underlying exchange occurs AND the resources are available. December sales occurred in Year 1. The $150,000 ($15M × 1%) is due January 20 and collectible by February 28 - within the 60-day availability period. Therefore, recognize $150,000 in Year 1. Resources are measurable (sales occurred) and available (collected within 60 days).
questions.tip: Derived tax revenues: Recognize when underlying transaction occurs AND resources are available (within availability period).

questions.question: Under GASB 84, which activity should be reported in a custodial fund?

options.A: Pension plan assets held for employee retirement
options.B: Taxes collected for another government and remitted within three days
options.C: Property taxes collected on behalf of a school district and held for 30+ days
options.D: Employee flexible spending account withholdings

questions.explanation: GASB 84 established custodial funds (replacing agency funds) for fiduciary activities that are not held in trust. Property taxes collected for another government and held before remittance should be reported in a custodial fund. Brief pass-through transactions (less than 3 months between receipt and disbursement) may use simplified reporting. Pension activities use pension trust funds. FSA withholdings are typically not fiduciary.
questions.tip: Custodial funds: Fiduciary activities without trust arrangement. Replace agency funds under GASB 84. Report additions and deductions.

questions.question: A city enters into an agreement with a manufacturer to abate property taxes for 10 years if the company creates 500 jobs. Under GASB 77, what disclosure is required?

options.A: Only the annual amount of taxes abated
options.B: Brief description of the program, including purpose and taxes abated
options.C: Record the abated taxes as an expenditure
options.D: No disclosure required until the 10-year period ends

questions.explanation: GASB 77 requires disclosure of tax abatement agreements that reduce tax revenues. Required disclosures include: brief description of the tax abatement program, authority under which it's entered into, eligibility criteria, how taxes are reduced, duration, dollar amount of taxes abated during the period, and commitments made by the recipient. No entry is made for foregone revenues.
questions.tip: Tax abatements: No revenue or expenditure recorded for foregone taxes. Disclosure required: program description, amount abated, commitments.

questions.question: A government enters a 3-year subscription arrangement for cloud-based software with annual payments of $120,000 due at year-end. The government's incremental borrowing rate is 5%. PV factor for 3-year ordinary annuity at 5% is 2.7232. What is the initial subscription liability?
questions.explanation: Under GASB 96, subscription-based IT arrangements (SBITAs) are accounted for similarly to leases under GASB 87. The subscription liability is recorded at the present value of subscription payments. Liability = $120,000 × 2.7232 = $326,784. A corresponding intangible right-to-use subscription asset is also recorded.
questions.tip: GASB 96 SBITAs: Similar to lease accounting. Record subscription liability at PV of payments and intangible right-to-use asset.

questions.question: A city enters into a 30-year arrangement where a private company will finance, build, and operate a parking garage on city land. The city will receive a share of revenues. Under GASB 94, how should the city report the arrangement if it's determined to be a service concession arrangement?

options.A: Report the garage as a city asset when construction is complete
options.B: Report only a receivable for future revenue share
options.C: Report a deferred inflow of resources when the arrangement begins
options.D: No reporting until the arrangement terminates

questions.explanation: Under GASB 94, for service concession arrangements (a type of public-private partnership), the transferor government reports: (1) the underlying asset (parking garage) at fair value, (2) a deferred inflow of resources for the difference between fair value and any upfront payment received, which is amortized over the arrangement term. The operator's investment in the facility creates a capital asset for the government.
questions.tip: GASB 94 service concessions: Report capital asset and deferred inflow. Deferred inflow amortized over the arrangement term.

questions.question: A city appoints a voting majority of a community college's board but does not impose financial benefit or burden on the college. The college has a separately elected board for operations. How should the city report its relationship?

options.A: Blended component unit
options.B: Discretely presented component unit
options.C: Related organization disclosed in notes
options.D: No reporting required

questions.explanation: The city appoints a voting majority (accountability criterion 1 met) but there is no financial benefit/burden relationship. Component units require both accountability criteria: appointment of majority AND either financial benefit/burden or fiscal dependency. Since the college is not fiscally dependent and there's no financial benefit/burden, it's a related organization requiring only note disclosure, not inclusion in financial statements.
questions.tip: Component unit requires: Appointment ability + Financial benefit/burden (or fiscal dependency). Without both = related organization (disclosure only).

questions.question: A city sells a major facility that had been used for decades. This type of sale is within management's control and is unusual for the city. How should this be reported?

options.A: Extraordinary item reported separately after operations
options.B: Special item reported separately before extraordinary items
options.C: Special item reported separately in the statement of activities
options.D: Included in regular program revenues or expenses

questions.explanation: Under GASB standards, special items are significant transactions within management's control that are either unusual in nature or infrequent in occurrence. Unlike FASB (which eliminated extraordinary item classification), GASB still distinguishes special items. A major facility sale is within management's control and unusual for the city, making it a special item reported separately in the statement of activities. GASB has not defined 'extraordinary items' the same way FASB previously did.
questions.tip: Special items (GASB): Significant, within management control, unusual OR infrequent. Report separately in statement of activities.

questions.question: A county's fiscal year ends June 30. Property taxes are levied October 1 for the subsequent calendar year (January-December). Taxes are due December 31. For the fiscal year ending June 30, Year 2, which levy provides the property tax revenue?

options.A: October 1, Year 1 levy (for calendar Year 2)
options.B: October 1, Year 0 levy (for calendar Year 1)
options.C: Both levies are partially recognized
options.D: October 1, Year 2 levy (for calendar Year 3)

questions.explanation: Property taxes are recognized in the fiscal period for which levied. The October 1, Year 1 levy is for calendar Year 2 (January-December Year 2). Fiscal year July 1, Year 1 - June 30, Year 2 includes January-June Year 2. The October Year 1 levy (for calendar Year 2) provides revenue for this fiscal year because January-June Year 2 is within the fiscal year ending June 30, Year 2.
questions.tip: Property tax timing: Match levy to fiscal year covered. Consider both levy date and period for which taxes are levied.
